Dear Ms. Anderson,

The Snyder op-ed piece, to which you link, asserts a connection between climate change and the Rwandan genocide which is no where evident in the historical record.

Snyder asserts that "declining agricultural production" made the Hutus covet Tutsi land, which resulted in the orgy of murder.

If there was a decline in agricultural production we are given no evidence of its size or nature. There is NO evidence that Rwanda's climate changed at all in the years before the genocide.

Recall the time and place, please; over 20 years ago just below the equator. In those days even the IPCC admitted that climate around the world was still well within historical records of natural variation, although they theorized that that soon would change. Their models suggested that climate change would be most readily detectable at the poles, not at the equator.

To blame the Rwandan genocide on climate change is not even speculation; it is revisionist history of the most blatant kind. The Rwandan genocide was only the latest episode in a centuries-old tribal hatred.

Snyder starts his op-ed piece with a Holocaust anecdote, a cheap rhetorical device avoided by all serious commentators. He fills his piece with error and speculation, then closes with a pious platitude about denying science.

Madame, when I point out that Snyder's op-ed piece is codswallop I do not deny science. I deny codswallop.

I think it's great to see charlatans standing, like Daffy Duck, on their respect for data and for science. Well, it's certainly at least hilarious.

Meanwhile back on the planet, any actual scientific concerns with the content of Revkin's article or the actual paper?

Susan, these are excellent points but an important issue is "who are WE?"

What does it mean to say that humanity wants something or should do something? What does it mean to say "The Democratic party thinks..."?
An army acts as a single agent, unfortunately, but can humanity act as "one" agent to solve its problems for which it clearly HAS the technology?

A lot of thinkers, mainly philosophers and philosophically minded computer scientists, have started to think about this issue.

I recommend: Infostorms by Hendricks and Hansen, Social Epistemology, edited by Goldman and Whitcomb, and Making the Social World, by Searle. There are many others but this is a start.

The real issue is closing the gap between those who have the ability to think and those who have the ability to stand up to grueling campaigns and money raising.

Good grief indeed. I suggest a basic education on greenhouse gases. Here's one answer: "water vapor has a short cycle in the atmosphere (a few days) before it is incorporated into weather events and falls to Earth, so it cannot build up in the atmosphere in the same way as carbon dioxide does." I was going to go straight to Wikipedia (not perfect, but useful and largely accurate) but instead suggest you do a search:

"heat trapping greenhouse gases"

which produced more accessible information than when last I looked. Here's an excellent overview with lots of good illustration and summary information:
https://www.climatecommunication.org/climate/heat-trapping-gases/

We are accumulating heat-trapping greenhouse gases in our atmosphere which are increasing the energy (heat) in the system (global warming) which is disrupting our planetary circulation (climate change). No about of Gore et al. bashing will change the facts, though you all may feel better for your free form insults.

Krugman has explained over and over again that fiscal policy is a far more efficient tool for recovering from a demand shock than monetary policy, but that if political reality obviates the possibility of effective fiscal stimulus, monetary stimulus is better than no action at all.

Raising interest rates have zero effect on the cost of producing petroleum products, because the capital investment has already been made, and because oil companies hardly need to borrow money before they can produce more oil. Exxon Mobil alone has $30 billion in cash and short-term investments. Do you really think it needs a high-interest loan? Do you think that Saudi Arabia determines how much oil it should produce by checking the U.S. interest rates?

Do you think the two percentage point drop in unemployment in the last two years would have happened if interest rates had been raised? 2.5 million more people are employed today than two years ago; do you think the oil industry lost 2.5 million jobs? Surprise! The number of oil jobs is flat since August 2013.
